message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Mathematical foundations of moral preferences
Paper Abstract: One-shot anonymous unselfishness in economic games is commonly explained by social preferences, which assume that people care about the monetary pay-offs of others. However, during the last 10 years, research has shown that different types of unselfish behaviour, including cooperation, altruism, truth-telling, altruistic punishment and trustworthiness are in fact better explained by preferences for following one's own personal norms—internal standards about what is right or wrong in a given situation. Beyond better organizing various forms of unselfish behaviour, this moral preference hypothesis has recently also been used to increase charitable donations, simply by means of interventions that make the morality of an action salient. Here we review experimental and theoretical work dedicated to this rapidly growing field of research, and in doing so we outline mathematical foundations for moral preferences that can be used in future models to better understand selfless human actions and to adjust policies accordingly. These foundations can also be used by artificial intelligence to better navigate the complex landscape of human morality.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "Altruistic punishment"

Links: [{"title":"Third-party punishment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Third-party_punishment"},{"title":"Tragedy of the commons - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comedy_of_the_commons"},{"title":"Altruism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altruism"},{"title":"Strong reciprocity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strong_reciprocity"},{"title":"Altruism (biology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altruism_(biology)"},{"title":"Empathy-altruism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Empathy-altruism"},{"title":"On the Genealogy of Morality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/On_the_Genealogy_of_Morals"},{"title":"Raffaele Garofalo - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raffaele_Garofalo"},{"title":"Reciprocity (social psychology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reciprocity_(social_psychology)"},{"title":"Altruism (ethics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altruism_(ethics)"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about altruistic punishment:

## Definition

Altruistic punishment entails the presence of individuals that punish defectors from a cooperative agreement, although doing so is costly and provides no material gain.

## Key Characteristics

People are willing to punish those who fail to cooperate, even when punishment is costly. This is a core component of a behavioral pattern called strong reciprocity.

## Types of Punishment

There are two types of punishment: second party and third party punishment. In second party punishment, the person who was hurt by the other parties' failure to cooperate has the opportunity to punish the non-cooperator. In third party punishment, an uninvolved third party has the opportunity to punish the non-cooperator.

## Evidence of Altruistic Punishment

Research has demonstrated this behavior across multiple experimental settings. Roughly 60% of third party observers chose to punish dictators who donated less than half their endowment. Additionally, altruistic punishment exists across many examined populations, but that there is also a large variance between them.

## Role in Cooperation

Studies have shown that punishment is an efficacious motivator for cooperation among humans. Altruistic punishment appears to play an important role in maintaining social norms and promoting cooperative behavior in groups.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Trustworthiness trust"

Links: [{"title":"Trust (social science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trust_(social_science)"},{"title":"Trust metric - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trust_metric"},{"title":"Trusted system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trusted_system"},{"title":"Credibility - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Credibility"},{"title":"Chain of trust - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chain_of_trust"},{"title":"Trust management (managerial science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trust_management_(managerial_science)"},{"title":"Trustworthy Software Foundation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trustworthy_Software_Foundation"},{"title":"Trustworthy AI - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trustworthy_AI"},{"title":"Trust and safety - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trust_and_safety"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Wikipedia Signpost/2022-09-30/Recent research - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Wikipedia_Signpost/2022-09-30/Recent_research"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about trustworthiness and trust:

## Key Definitions

Trustworthiness refers to the characteristics or behaviors of one person that inspire positive expectations in another person. In contrast, trust is the belief that another person will do what is expected, and it brings with it a willingness for one party (the trustor) to become vulnerable to another party (the trustee), on the presumption that the trustee will act in ways that benefit the trustor.

## Trust Propensity and Types

Trust propensity is the tendency to make oneself vulnerable to others in general. Additionally, scholars distinguish between generalized trust (also known as social trust), which is the extension of trust to a relatively large circle of unfamiliar others, and particularized trust, which is contingent on a specific situation or a specific relationship.

## Relationship to Credibility

Credibility has two key components: trustworthiness and expertise, which both have objective and subjective components.(no content)Trustworthiness is based more on subjective factors, but can include objective measurements such as established reliability.

## Economic Perspective

Theoretical economical modelling demonstrates that the optimum level of trust that a rational economic agent should exhibit in transactions is equal to the trustworthiness of the other party, which leads to an efficient market, while trusting less leads to losing economic opportunities, and trusting more leads to unnecessary vulnerabilities and potential exploitation.

Links: [{"title":"Artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Artificial general intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_general_intelligence"},{"title":"Applications of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Applications_of_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Timeline of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence in video games - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_in_video_games"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence visual art - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_art"},{"title":"Artificial Intelligence: A Modern Approach - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_Intelligence:_A_Modern_Approach"},{"title":"List of artificial intelligence films - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_artificial_intelligence_films"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence arms race - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_arms_race"},{"title":"Ethics of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethics_of_artificial_intelligence"}]

## Artificial Intelligence Overview

I've completed the web search for "Artificial intelligence." Here are the key findings:

### Definition and Core Concept
Artificial intelligence (AI) is the capability of computational systems to perform tasks typically associated with human intelligence, such as learning, reasoning, problem-solving, perception, and decision-making.

### Historical Background
Artificial intelligence was founded as an academic discipline in 1956, and the field went through multiple cycles of optimism throughout its history, followed by periods of disappointment and loss of funding, known as AI winters.

### Key Research Goals
The traditional goals of AI research include learning, reasoning, knowledge representation, planning, natural language processing, perception, and support for robotics.

### Artificial General Intelligence (AGI)
Some companies, such as OpenAI, Google DeepMind and Meta, aim to create artificial general intelligence (AGI) – AI that can complete virtually any cognitive task at least as well as a human.

### Modern Applications
AI is now widely used across many domains, including:
- Generative artificial intelligence (Generative AI, or GenAI) is a subfield of artificial intelligence that uses generative models to generate text, images, videos, audio, software code or other forms of data.
- Artificial intelligence is used in astronomy to analyze increasing amounts of available data and applications for classification, regression, clustering, forecasting, generation, discovery, and the development of new scientific insights, including discovering exoplanets and forecasting solar activity.

The search results cover the definition, history, research approaches, current applications, and emerging concerns related to AI development.

Web search results for query: "Morality ethics philosophy"

Links: [{"title":"Ethics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethics"},{"title":"Morality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morality"},{"title":"The Elements of Moral Philosophy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Elements_of_Moral_Philosophy"},{"title":"History of ethics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_ethics"},{"title":"Outline of ethics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outline_of_ethics"},{"title":"Modern Moral Philosophy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modern_Moral_Philosophy"},{"title":"Science of morality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Science_of_morality"},{"title":"Metaethics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metaethics"},{"title":"Moral foundations theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moral_foundations_theory"},{"title":"Category:Ethical theories - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Ethical_theories"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of morality, ethics, and philosophy:

## Definition and Relationship

Ethics is the philosophical study of moral phenomena. Also called moral philosophy, it investigates normative questions about what people ought to do or which behavior is morally right.(no content)The terms ethics and morality are usually used interchangeably but some philosophers distinguish between the two. According to one view, morality focuses on what moral obligations people have while ethics is broader and includes ideas about what is good and how to lead a meaningful life.

## Main Branches of Ethics

The main branches include normative ethics, applied ethics, and metaethics. Normative ethics aims to find general principles that govern how people should act. Applied ethics examines concrete ethical problems in real-life situations, such as abortion, treatment of animals, and business practices. Metaethics explores the underlying assumptions and concepts of ethics. It asks whether there are objective moral facts, how moral knowledge is possible, and how moral judgments motivate people.

## Major Ethical Theories

Influential normative theories are consequentialism, deontology, and virtue ethics. According to consequentialists, an act is right if it leads to the best consequences. Deontologists focus on acts themselves, saying that they must adhere to duties, like telling the truth and keeping promises.

## Historical Development

The history of ethics started in the ancient period with the development of ethical principles and theories in ancient Egypt, India, China, and Greece. This period saw the emergence of ethical teachings associated with Hinduism, Buddhism, Confucianism, Daoism, and contributions of philosophers like Socrates and Aristotle.

Web search results for query: "Cooperation behavior"

Links: [{"title":"Cooperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperation"},{"title":"Cooperation (evolution) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperation_(evolution)"},{"title":"Cooperative game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperative_game_theory"},{"title":"Coopetition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coopetition"},{"title":"Cooperative - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperative"},{"title":"Cooperative pulling paradigm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperative_pulling_paradigm"},{"title":"Cooperativeness - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperativeness"},{"title":"Global Co-opetition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_Co-opetition"},{"title":"Cooperative strategy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperative_strategy"},{"title":"Microbial cooperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microbial_cooperation"}]

I've performed a web search on "Cooperation behavior" and found comprehensive information. Here's an overview of what was found:

## Definition and Overview

In evolution, cooperation is the process where groups of organisms work or act together for common or mutual benefits.(no content)It is commonly defined as any adaptation that has evolved, at least in part, to increase the reproductive success of the actor's social partners.

## Cooperation Across Species

Cooperation exists not only in humans but in other animals as well, with the diversity of taxa that exhibits cooperation being quite large, ranging from zebra herds to pied babblers to African elephants.(no content)Chimpanzees, bonobos, orangutans, tamarins, capuchins, elephants, wolves, ravens, and kea appear to understand how cooperation works.

## Psychological Aspects

Fairness affects human cooperation; individuals are willing to punish at their own cost (altruistic punishment) if they believe that they are being treated unfairly. Additionally, cooperativeness is a personality trait that concerns how much a person is generally agreeable in their relations with other people as opposed to aggressively self-centered and hostile.

## Evolutionary Basis

Kin selection or related inclusive fitness theory is defined as a reproductive strategy that favors the success of an organism's relatives, even when it is not in an organism's own best interest, it's highly relevant to human social behavior, relationships and cooperation.

## Business and Organizational Cooperation

Cooperative Strategy refers to a planning strategy in which two or more firms work together in order to achieve a common objective.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Altruism psychology"

Links: [{"title":"Psychological barriers to effective altruism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychological_barriers_to_effective_altruism"},{"title":"Altruism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altruism"},{"title":"Pathological Altruism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pathological_Altruism"},{"title":"Reciprocal altruism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reciprocal_altruism"},{"title":"Kin selection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kin_selection"},{"title":"Naïve cynicism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Na%C3%AFve_cynicism"},{"title":"Nancy Eisenberg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nancy_Eisenberg"},{"title":"Prosocial behavior - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prosocial_behavior"},{"title":"Agreeableness - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agreeableness"},{"title":"Inclusive fitness - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inclusive_fitness"}]

I've found comprehensive information about altruism from a psychology perspective. Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Basic Concept

In simple terms, altruism is caring about the welfare of other people and acting to help them, above oneself.(no content)The purest forms of prosocial behavior are motivated by altruism, an unselfish interest in helping another person.

## Psychological Perspectives

There's ongoing debate about whether true altruism exists. The theory of psychological egoism suggests that no act of sharing, helping, or sacrificing can be "truly" altruistic, as the actor may receive an intrinsic reward in the form of personal gratification.

## Evolutionary Explanations

Animals and humans are more altruistic towards close kin than to distant kin and non-kin has been confirmed in numerous studies across many different cultures.(no content)Throughout human evolutionary history, residing in small, tightly-knit groups has given rise to prosocial emotions and intentions towards kin and ingroup members, rather than universally extending to those outside the group boundaries.

## Brain and Emotional Aspects

Research shows altruism has neurological basis. Both pure monetary rewards and charitable donations activated the mesolimbic reward pathway, a primitive part of the brain that usually responds to food and sex. However, when volunteers generously placed the interests of others before their own by making charitable donations, another brain circuit was also selectively activated: the subgenual cortex/septal region.(no content)Batson's empathy-altruism model examines the emotional and motivational component of prosocial behavior. Feeling empathy towards the individual needing aid increases the likelihood that the aid will be given.

## Psychological Barriers

Altruistic motives are distorted by, among other things, parochialism, status seeking and conformity.

Links: [{"title":"Psychological barriers to effective altruism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychological_barriers_to_effective_altruism"},{"title":"Altruism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altruism"},{"title":"Pathological Altruism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pathological_Altruism"},{"title":"Reciprocal altruism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reciprocal_altruism"},{"title":"Kin selection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kin_selection"},{"title":"Naïve cynicism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Na%C3%AFve_cynicism"},{"title":"Nancy Eisenberg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nancy_Eisenberg"},{"title":"Prosocial behavior - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prosocial_behavior"},{"title":"Agreeableness - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agreeableness"},{"title":"Inclusive fitness - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inclusive_fitness"}]

I've found comprehensive information about altruism from a psychology perspective. Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Basic Concept

In simple terms, altruism is caring about the welfare of other people and acting to help them, above oneself.(no content)The purest forms of prosocial behavior are motivated by altruism, an unselfish interest in helping another person.

## Psychological Perspectives

There's ongoing debate about whether true altruism exists. The theory of psychological egoism suggests that no act of sharing, helping, or sacrificing can be "truly" altruistic, as the actor may receive an intrinsic reward in the form of personal gratification.

## Evolutionary Explanations

Animals and humans are more altruistic towards close kin than to distant kin and non-kin has been confirmed in numerous studies across many different cultures.(no content)Throughout human evolutionary history, residing in small, tightly-knit groups has given rise to prosocial emotions and intentions towards kin and ingroup members, rather than universally extending to those outside the group boundaries.

## Brain and Emotional Aspects

Research shows altruism has neurological basis. Both pure monetary rewards and charitable donations activated the mesolimbic reward pathway, a primitive part of the brain that usually responds to food and sex. However, when volunteers generously placed the interests of others before their own by making charitable donations, another brain circuit was also selectively activated: the subgenual cortex/septal region.(no content)Batson's empathy-altruism model examines the emotional and motivational component of prosocial behavior. Feeling empathy towards the individual needing aid increases the likelihood that the aid will be given.

## Psychological Barriers

Altruistic motives are distorted by, among other things, parochialism, status seeking and conformity.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Social preferences economics"

Links: [{"title":"Social preferences - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_preferences"},{"title":"Preference (economics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Preference_(economics)"},{"title":"Social choice theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_choice_theory"},{"title":"Social Choice and Individual Values - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_Choice_and_Individual_Values"},{"title":"Social welfare function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_welfare_function"},{"title":"Social value orientations - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_Value_Orientations"},{"title":"Preference - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Preferential"},{"title":"Welfare economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Socially_optimal"},{"title":"Time preference - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_preference"},{"title":"Rational choice model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rational_choice_model"}]

Here are the search results for "Social preferences economics":

## Overview

Social preferences describe the human tendency to not only care about one's own material payoff, but also the reference group's payoff or/and the intention that leads to the payoff.(no content)Social preferences are studied extensively in behavioral and experimental economics and social psychology.

## Key Types

Types of social preferences include altruism, fairness, reciprocity, and inequity aversion.

## Historical Development

The research of social preferences in economics started with lab experiments in 1980, where experimental economists found subjects' behavior deviated systematically from self-interest behavior in economic games such as ultimatum game and dictator game.(no content)These experimental findings then inspired various new economic models to characterize agent's altruism, fairness and reciprocity concern between 1990 and 2010.

## Experimental Games

The ultimatum game, the dictator game, the trust game and the gift-exchange game are exercises that used to understand social preferences and their implications. For example, the ultimatum game is one of the first experiments that shows self-interest hypothesis fails to predict people's behavior. In this game, the first mover proposes a split of a fixed amount, and the second mover decides to accept or reject the offer. If the second mover accepts the offer, the final payoff is exactly determined by the offer. However, if the second mover rejects the offer, both subjects will have zero payoff.

## Related Concept: Social Value Orientation

In social psychology, social value orientation (SVO) is a person's preference about how to allocate resources (e.g. money) between the self and another person. SVO corresponds to how much weight a person attaches to the welfare of others in relation to the own.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Truth-telling ethics"

Links: [{"title":"Ethics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethics"},{"title":"Honesty - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Honesty"},{"title":"Journalism ethics and standards - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Journalism_ethics_and_standards"},{"title":"Speaking truth to power - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Speaking_truth_to_power"},{"title":"Post-truth politics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Post-truth_politics"},{"title":"Christian views on lying - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christian_views_on_lying"},{"title":"Truthfulness - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Truthfulness"},{"title":"Post-truth - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Post-truth"},{"title":"Truth - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Truth"},{"title":"Truth-seeking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Truth-seeking"}]

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of truth-telling ethics:

## Philosophical Approaches

Truth-telling is considered a principle in deontological ethics, along with keeping promises and not intentionally harming others.(no content)According to rule consequentialism, a person should tell the truth even in specific cases where lying would lead to better consequences.

## Honesty as a Moral Value

Honesty or truthfulness is a facet of moral character that connotes positive and virtuous attributes such as integrity, truthfulness, straightforwardness, along with the absence of lying, cheating, and theft.(no content)Immanuel Kant made the duty of honesty a core example of his ethical theories.

## Religious and Historical Perspectives

Lying is strongly discouraged and forbidden by most interpretations of Christianity, with arguments based on various biblical passages, especially "Thou shalt not bear false witness against thy neighbour", one of the Ten Commandments. However, among early Christian writers, there existed differing viewpoints regarding the ethics of deception and dishonesty in certain circumstances, with some arguing that lying could be justified for reasons such as saving souls or convincing reluctant candidates to accept ordination.

## Truth-Telling as Resistance

Truth-telling underlines itself as a form of ethical resistance, emphasizing a commitment not only to personal integrity but also to societal welfare.(no content)The phrase "Speak Truth to Power" originated with the Quaker community, and for Quakers, this practice transcends strategy; it represents a moral duty tied to justice and ethical integrity.

## Contemporary Concerns

Proposed solutions to post-truth politics include an ethical commitment to truth-telling and fact-checking in public, protecting the integrity of political institutions, and improving information literacy with education.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
Perfect! All tasks have been completed successfully. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Survey paper - This work reviews experimental and theoretical research on moral preferences rather than proposing novel methods.

**Key Entities Extracted (8 triples):**

1. **Social preferences** - Foundational concept reviewed in the paper explaining unselfish behavior
2. **Cooperation** - Type of unselfish behavior studied via moral preferences framework
3. **Altruism** - Central behavior better explained by moral preferences than social preferences
4. **Honesty** - Truth-telling identified as unselfish behavior within moral preferences
5. **Strong reciprocity** - Framework including altruistic punishment explained by moral preferences
6. **Trust (social science)** - Trustworthiness as unselfish behavior explained by moral preferences
7. **Morality** - Core concept with mathematical foundations proposed as explanatory framework
8. **Artificial intelligence** - Application area for moral preference research

**Validation Result:** ✅ All validation checks passed with 8 concepts successfully mapped to Wikipedia articles.

Sources used for entity identification:
